Musk will donate to Reform if there is a legal way for him to do so. If the government, or the people whom they purportedly represent decide that they do not want there to be a legal way to do so, then the law can be written.... only it wont be, because there is no way to write it in a way that 1) wont be challenged in the courts for being discriminatory, or 2) wont F in the A those in a position to make the law who also massively benefit from large donations form foreign citizens.

Both examples are citizens of one country interfering with an election in another. A billionaire is still an individual paying out of their own pocket. I'm not saying I'm for or against Musk donating to Reform. Interestingly, if Musk simply came to the UK on a student or work visa he'd instantly be eligible to vote in the UK. We've had South African MPs in the UK before. So the line on what is "foreign and therefore unacceptable" really isn't being drawn clearly here.  

But the point is, none of the people in these comments get angry when:
- The largest donation in Labour party history comes from an offshore hedge fund weeks before the election
- Starmer was the only candidate in the Labour leadership race to fail to register his campaign donors
- Starmer receives extensive support from the head of the Russian-linked Nevsky Fund, which owns huge amounts of Russian assets
- Starmer's own staff runs off to campaign in another country for Kamala Harris, massively pissing off the next President

I doubt most people in the comments ever even heard about several of those examples, because the news wasn't telling them to get angry about it. But it's telling them to get angry about this, so they are.

The stagnation on the continent is as unavoidable as our own. Tearing down workers' rights and allowing the pockets of billionairs to be lined is not a serious solution to the problems Europe has. Greater investment in education, infrastructure and the strengthening of the average household's income *are* serious solutions. Reform is proposing the former, not the latter.

>We should have left later, actually.

Despite what former banker and toad faced liar [Nigel Farage said?](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/nigel-farage-brexit-article-50-triggered-response-point-of-no-return-eu-a7656436.html)

>Well, going with your example, if you're looking for someone hung like a horse, and you've slept with two of the four contenders. It sounds pretty reasonable to avoid the ones you've seen. 

Except Labour never pretended, and still aren't pretending, there are easy routes out of our current situation - unlike Reform. You are simply not thinking this through enough to resist someone falsely selling you a way out of a difficult situation. You would rather gamble on a quick fix, which is almost certainly not going to happen, than take the mild discomfort of following the actual way. 

You act like experimenting with Reform would be harmleas, while ignoring the fact they follow the economic philosophy of Truss and Kwarteng. Voting Reform in the hope they will solve the woes of a situation their leader helped create is like emailing back the Nigerian prince in your spam folder. You will get no solution. You will just be left scammed and poorer.

>Until then, I will vote for the closest alternative to my view.

Given the sheer incoherence and naivety behind all the points you have made, you may end up actually voting for party that will deliver something very much opposed to your view.
